prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for telling my friend she’s still single due to having 5 babies by different fathers?
She finished her 5th divorce two years ago, and for these two years she keeps asking me questions that also insult me.

 “How did you get a man at 30 with kids? It’s because you’re so skinny.” 

“Do I have to stop eating like you? Haha haha”

“You has so many dates. Guys only want basic blondes who are girly.”

“Did you only talk about sex with them?!”

For two years I’ve brushed off the insults, and replied: “ You’re in a small town” or “focus on yourself , and someone special will come around”

Finally she asks for the billionth time “How did you get any dates at 30 with kids?!? You don’t even have a real job! Tell me the truth- why can’t I get anyone?”

I replied honestly and said: “ You have five kids with different dads and none of them pay child support. It’s going to be hard for someone to accept that when you openly are looking for a father figure.”

This launched her into an insult fury, and she hung up on me. 

For reference: I’m not skinny but I work out (healthy weight). I eat more than her, honestly, not starving. I’m girly about some things I guess. I have two kids by the same dad and we split custody 50/50. I work in the adult industry, but only need to put in 8-10 hours a week to make a way better than average income. She keeps insulting my work even though she tried to do it, as well. I also have a vanilla job and an MBA. 

I was tired of being hit low quality and untrue insults, so I replied with what I thought was the truth.

Now, all of our mutual friends are saying I have skinny privilege and such. I’m entitled and don’t understand what she’s going through. They said it was messed up to say that and I’m a shitty friend, and I get whatever I want. She’s not going through anything that major. She’s just dating and being a mom like I had to do. 

Now I’m stuck with my mouth shut, and I’m mad at everyone because I’m not privileged or entitled at all- I’ve worked very hard for anything and everything I have.  And side note- the girl keeps talking about her

AITA for saying that? Was there a better thing to say? 
"""

I think the author is not in the wrong, but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's try to figure out if the author is in the wrong here. So, the situation is that the author's friend has gone through five divorces and has five kids with different fathers. The friend keeps making comments to the author that come off as insults, questioning why the author has a partner and kids when she (the friend) doesn't. The author tried to brush off these comments for two years, giving vague advice. Then, when the friend asked again, the author responded by pointing out the friend's situation with the kids and lack of child support as a possible reason. The friend got angry and hung up. Now, mutual friends are criticizing the author, saying they have "skinny privilege" and are being a bad friend.

First, I need to consider if the author's response was appropriate. The friend's comments were clearly hurtful and insinuating that the author's success in relationships (or perceived success) was due to superficial reasons like being skinny or more attractive. The author, feeling attacked, responded with what they believe is the truth: the friend's situation with multiple kids from different fathers might make it harder to find someone. 

But is pointing out that truth okay? The friend's behavior included insults and passive-aggressive questions, which the author tried to handle politely. However, when the author finally responded with the truth, it caused a fallout. The friends are now taking sides against the author, saying they're privileged and not understanding the friend's struggles. 

On one hand, the author was defending themselves after being insulted. They have their own valid reasons for feeling targeted. On the other hand, the author's response was direct and possibly hurtful, even if true. The line between giving honest feedback and being cruel can be thin. The author might have been justified in feeling defensive, but the way they communicated it could have been more empathetic.

The friend's actions included repeated insults, which is part of the problem. The author's response, while honest, might have been the trigger that ended the friendship, but it was in response to years of one-sided interactions where the author felt attacked. 

I think the key points are: the friend's behavior was problematic and the insults were unwarranted. The author's response was a direct consequence of being pushed too far. While the author's truth might be valid, the delivery could have been more tactful. However, the main issue is that the friend was the one making the insults, and the author was finally asserting themselves. So, the author isn't entirely in the wrong. They were responding to ongoing issues. But maybe there was a better way to approach it. Still, the fault lies more with the friend for the initial insults and the author's response was a reaction to that. So the answer is B (No), the author isn't in the wrong.
